newsitem.title: UK: Optical fibres -- nature got there first.
newsitem.headline: Optical fibres -- nature got there first.

text.p: Optical fibres, the invention at the heart of late 20th century telecommunications, occur naturally in the chilly waters of the Antarctic, a group of scientists claimed on Wednesday.
The creature they identified as having stolen a march of several millenia on the world's telecom giants is the humble Antarctic hexactinellid, or sponge.
The scientists, from three Italian zoological and biological institutes, wrote in the journal Nature that they had examined spicules which protrude some 10 cm (four inches) from the creature's body.
The spicules were bent at a 90 degree angle. They shone a laser beam down them and discovered that the spicules showed similar light-carrying properties to optical fibres.
"The intensity of the light immediately after the bend ...reached 65 percent after 10 millimetres...decreasing to about 10 percent after 40 millimetres," they reported.
The scientists suggested that the light-transferring properties of the spicules helped the survival of microscopic unicellular algae known as diatoms, which live deep inside the sponges.
